sen.j: 武蔵国（むさしのくに）は、かつて日本の地方行政区分だった令制国の一つ。
sen.e: Musashi Province was one of the provinces administered in the past by the 'ryo-sei' or administrative codes.
Musashi Province was one of the provinces administered by the 'ryo-sei,' or administrative codes.
Musashi Province was one of the provinces administered by the Ryo-sei, or administrative codes.

sen.j: 現在の埼玉県、東京都の隅田川より東の地域と島嶼を除く部分、および神奈川県の北東部（現在の川崎市全域と横浜市東部・沿岸部）を合わせた地域に当たる。
sen.e: The province matches the combined area of Saitama Prefecture, the eastern part from the Sumida River in Tokyo excluding Shimakyo, and the northeast of Kanagawa Prefecture (present-day entire Kawasaki City and the eastern and coastal parts of Yokohama City).

The province matches the combined area of Saitama Prefecture, the eastern part from the Sumida River in Tokyo (excluding Shimakyo), and the northeast of Kanagawa Prefecture (including all of the present-day Kawasaki City and the eastern and coastal parts of Yokohama City).

The province was equal in size to the combined areas of present-day Saitama Prefecture, the part of Tokyo east of the Sumida River (excluding Shimakyo), and the northeastern part of Kanagawa Prefecture (all of present-day Kawasaki City and the eastern and coastal parts of Yokohama City).
sen.cmt: "matches" is too vague as it would leave the reader wondering in what way the province "matches" the combined areas given.

sen.j: 武州（ぶしゅう）と呼ぶこともある。
sen.e: It is also called Bushu.
It is also called Bushu.
It is also called Bushu.

sen.j: 延喜式での格は国司国等級区分、遠国。
sen.e: The status of the Engishiki is 'Engoku' or far province in the criteria of Kokushi-Kokutokyu-kubun..
The status of the Engishiki is 'Engoku (far province),' based on the criteria of Kokushi-Kokutokyu-kubun.

Its status under the Engishiki (a book of laws and regulation compiled during the Engi era) was Engoku, meaning distant province, in the Kokushi-Kokutokyu-kubun (classification of provinces according to their political and economic situation) category.
sen.cmt: Even with some knowledge of Japanese, a native speaker of English would have no idea what this meant. To be fair, the exact meaning of "国司国等級区分" here is very unclear (some explanation should be provided), but it took me less than five minutes to come up with a rough explanation of "延喜式". The main problem, however, is that, if my understanding is correct, the translation is simply wrong. It is not the status of the Engishiki that is being discussed but the status of Musashi Province under the Engishiki set of laws and regulations.「国司国等級区分」の補足として(classification of provinces according to their political and economic situation) を挿入しました。

sen.j: 飛鳥京・藤原宮木簡には、无耶志国と表記。
sen.e: The province is described as Muzashi Province in the wooden tablets from the Fujiwara palace site in Asuka-kyo.
The province is described as Muzashi Province in the wooden tablets from the site of Fujiwara Palace in Asuka-kyo.
The province is described as Muzashi Province in the wooden tablets from the site of Fujiwara Palace in Asuka-kyo.

sen.j: また、7世紀頃までの武蔵は「无射志」（むざし）と表記されていた記録も見つかっている。
sen.e: In addition, there was a finding that Musashi had been represented by the different kanji ''Muzashi' until the seventh century.
Additionally, it has been found that Musashi was represented differently, as the kanji ''Muzashi,' until the seventh century.
Additionally, it has been found that Musashi was represented differently, as the kanji 'Muzashi,' until the seventh century.

sen.j: 6世紀の武蔵国造の乱の後、7世紀に成立した。
sen.e: Musashi Province was established in the seventh century after the Musashinokuni-no-Miyatsuko no Ran in the sixth century.
Musashi Province was established in the seventh century, after the Musashinokuni-no-Miyatsuko no Ran of the sixth century.
Musashi Province was established in the seventh century, after the Musashinokuni-no-Miyatsuko no Ran (Musashinokuni-no-Miyatsuko Rebellion) of the sixth century.

sen.j: 胸刺（むざし）と无邪志（むざし）、知知夫（ちちぶ）が１つの国になったとされる。
sen.e: It is known Muzashi (胸刺(むざし)), Muzashi (无邪志(むざし)), and Chichibu (知知夫(ちちぶ)) were combined to form Musashi Province.
It is known that Muzashi (胸刺(むざし)), Muzashi (无邪志(むざし)) and Chichibu (知知夫(ちちぶ)) were combined to form Musashi Province.
It is known that Muzashi (胸刺(むざし)), Muzashi (无邪志(むざし)) and Chichibu (知知夫(ちちぶ)) were combined to form Musashi Province.

sen.j: 武蔵国造の乱で献上された南部（多氷）に国府が置かれた。
sen.e: The ancient provincial capital was established in Minabe (Ohohi) which was received after the Musashinokuni-no-Miyatsuko no Ran.
sen.cmt: Webster's Online Dictionaryhttp://homepage3.nifty.com/hoshino/Sakitama/Miyatsuko/Miyatsuko.htmlOhohiの母音はよいのでしょうか。
sen.e: The ancient provincial capital was established in Minabe (Ohohi), which was received after the Musashinokuni-no-Miyatsuko no Ran.
The ancient provincial capital was established in Minabe (Ohohi), which was received after the Musashinokuni-no-Miyatsuko no Ran.

sen.j: 当初は毛野国との関係で東山道に属し、東山道武蔵路が設けられていた。
sen.e: Because of the relationship with Keno Province, Musashi Province, at first, belonged to Tosando, and accordingly the Tosando Musashi-michi Road was built.
Because of the relationship with Keno Province, Musashi Province initially belonged to Tosando, and accordingly the Tosando Musashi-michi Road was built.
Because of the relationship with Keno Province, Musashi Province initially belonged to Tosando, and accordingly the Tosando Musashi-michi Road was built.

sen.j: 708年（和銅元年）、秩父郡（ちちぶのこおり）で和銅（精錬の必要の無い自然銅）が発見された。
sen.e: Japanese copper, native copper without the need of refining, was found In 708, in Chichibu District,
Japanese copper, a domestic type that doesn't need refining, was found in the Chichibu district in the year 708.
Japanese copper, a domestic type that doesn't need refining, was found in the Chichibu district in the year 708.

sen.j: 771年 (宝亀2年) 10月27日 (旧暦)に東海道に移された。
sen.e: On December 11, 771, Musashi Province was transferred to Tokaido from Tosando.
On December 11 in the year 771, Musashi Province was transferred to Tokaido from Tosando.
Musashi Province was transferred to Tokaido from Tosando on October 27, 771.

sen.j: 平安時代の927年（延長5年）に完成した延喜式によると、官営による4つの勅旨牧が置かれた。
sen.e: According to the Engishiki completed in 927 in the Heian period, four farms or 'chokushi-maki' (勅旨牧) run by the government were built.
According to the Engishiki, which was completed in 927 during the Heian period, four government-run farms, or 'chokushi-maki (勅旨牧),' were built.
According to the Engishiki, which was completed in 927 during the Heian period, four government-run farms, or Chokushi-maki (勅旨牧), were built.

sen.j: これらは朝廷に毎年50頭の良馬を納めていた。
sen.e: The farms offered 50 of good horses to the Imperial court every year.
Each year the farms would present 50 good horses to the Imperial Court.
Each year the farms would present 50 good horses to the Imperial Court.

sen.j: その後も勅旨牧は増設され、軍用品の生産地として重要視されるようになった。
sen.e: They were expanded thereafter, and were treated as an important production site for military supplies.
The farms were subsequently expanded and treated as important production sites for military supplies.
The farms were subsequently expanded and treated as important production sites for military supplies.

sen.j: 中央から軍事貴族が派遣され、在庁官人が実務を担った。
sen.e: Military nobles were sent from the capital, and local officials (zaicho-kanjin) were in charge of the day-to-day business.
Military nobles were sent from the capital, and local officials (zaicho-kanjin) were in charge of the day-to-day business operations.
Military nobles were sent from the capital, and local officials (zaicho-kanjin) were in charge of the day-to-day business operations.

sen.j: 対立もあり、939年（天慶2年）の源経基と武蔵武芝の争いは承平天慶の乱の遠因となった。
sen.e: Conflicts erupted among them, and the clash between MINAMOTO no Tsunemoto and MUSASHI no Takeshiba in 939 almost marked the beginning of Johei Tengyo no Ran.
Conflicts erupted among them, and in 939 the clash between MINAMOTO no Tsunemoto and MUSASHI no Takeshiba nearly triggered the beginning of Johei Tengyo no Ran.
Conflicts erupted among them, and in 939 the clash between MINAMOTO no Tsunemoto and MUSASHI no Takeshiba nearly triggered the beginning of Johei Tengyo no Ran (Johei Tengyo Rebellion).

sen.j: その後、牧の管理者の中から同族的武士団が生まれ割拠した。
sen.e: Out of the administrators of the farms, tribal warrior bands emerged and prospered.
Out of the administrators of the farms, tribal warrior bands emerged and prospered.
Out of the administrators of the farms, tribal warrior bands emerged and prospered.

sen.j: それらは後の世に武蔵七党と呼ばれることとなる。
sen.e: Those groups were later known as 'musashi-shichito' or seven warrior bands of Musashi Province.
Those groups were later known as the 'musashi-shichito,' or the seven warrior bands of Musashi Province.
Those groups were later known as the Musashi-shichito, or the seven warrior bands of Musashi Province.

sen.j: 彼らは鎌倉幕府成立の大きな力となり、幕府を支えた。
sen.e: They played a major role in establishing the Kamakura Bakufu, and supported the government.
They played a major role in establishing the Kamakura Bakufu, and supported the government.
They played a major role in establishing the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), and supported the bakufu.
sen.cmt: 幕府に(Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) を補足しました。

sen.j: 反面、鎌倉に政権が置かれると、地元の有力勢力は排除され、南関東は政権のお膝元（関東御分国）として再編されていった。
sen.e: As the government was placed in Kamakura, strong local families were removed, the southern Kanto region was reorganized as an adjacent area (Kanto-gobunkoku) of the government.
The government was placed in Kamakura, and as a result strong local families were removed and the southern Kanto region was reorganized by the government as an adjacent area (Kanto-gobunkoku).

The government was placed in Kamakura, and as a result strong local families were removed and the southern Kanto region was reorganized by the government as an adjacent area (called "Kanto-gobunkoku").

sen.j: 周辺の国々では上総氏や三浦氏（和田氏）など有力在庁官人が滅亡した。
sen.e: Powerful local officials including the Kazusa clan and the Miura clan (Wada clan) were defeated in the neighboring provinces.
Powerful local officials, including the Kazusa and Miura clans (Wada clan), were defeated in the neighboring provinces.
Powerful local officials, including the Kazusa and Miura clans (Wada clan), were defeated in the neighboring provinces.

sen.j: 武蔵国でも比企氏、畠山氏 (平姓)が滅ぼされた。
sen.e: The Hiki clan and the Hatakeyama clan (Hei-sei) were defeated in Musashi Province.
The Hiki and Hatakeyama clans (Hei-sei) were defeated in Musashi Province.
The Hiki and Hatakeyama clans (of Taira family) were defeated in Musashi Province.
sen.cmt: (平姓)を of Taira familyとしました。

sen.j: 秩父氏の力は衰え、北条氏得宗が実権を握った。
sen.e: The Chichibu clan declined, and Hojo clan Tokuso took over the control of the province.
With the decline of the Chichibu clan, the Hojo clan Tokuso seized control of the province.
With the decline of the Chichibu clan, the Hojo clan Tokuso seized control of the province.

sen.j: 武蔵国は中小武士団が栄える国となった。
sen.e: Musashi Province became a province where small to medium-sized warrior bands thrived.
Musashi Province became a province in which small to medium-size warrior bands thrived.
Musashi Province became a province in which small to medium-size warrior bands thrived.

sen.j: 室町時代になっても状況は変わらなかった。
sen.e: The situation did not change even after the Muromachi period began.
The situation did not change, even after the start of the Muromachi period.
The situation did not change, even after the start of the Muromachi period.

sen.j: 鎌倉には鎌倉府が置かれた。
sen.e: The Kamakura-fu was established in Kamakura.
The Kamakura-fu was established in Kamakura.
The Kamakura-fu (government of Kamakura) was established in Kamakura.

sen.j: 秩父氏は武蔵平一揆の乱で力を失い、武蔵国の実権は関東管領上杉氏が握った。
sen.e: The Chichibu clan lost its power in the Musashi Hei Ikki no Ran (武蔵平一揆の乱), and Kanto Kanrei 'the Uesugi clan' took over Musashi Province.
The Chichibu clan lost its power in the Musashi Hei Ikki no Ran (武蔵平一揆の乱), and Kanto Kanrei--the Uesugi clan--took over Musashi Province.

The Chichibu clan lost its power in the Musashi Hei Ikki no Ran (Musashi Hei Riot Rebellion (武蔵平一揆の乱)), and the Uesugi clan of Kanto Kanrei (a position to support the chief of Kamakura-fu) took over Musashi Province.
sen.cmt: Musashi Hei Riot Rebellion 追加 関東管領の補足として (a position to support the chief of Kamakura-fu) を挿入しました。

sen.j: 武蔵国の中小武士団は武州南一揆や北一揆を結成した。
sen.e: Small to medium-sized warrior bands in Musashi Province formed factions called the Musashi Hei Ikki and the Kita Ikki.
Small to medium-size warrior bands in Musashi Province formed factions, which were called the Musashi Hei Ikki and Kita Ikki.
Small to medium-size warrior bands in Musashi Province formed factions, which were called the Musashi Hei Ikki and Kita Ikki.

sen.j: その後関東では室町幕府と鎌倉府の対立、鎌倉府と関東管領の対立、扇谷上杉家と山内上杉家の対立、両上杉家と家宰（太田道灌や長尾景春）の対立が続いた。
sen.e: After that, in the Kanto region, clashes continued between the Muromachi Bakufu and the Kamakura-fu, between the Kamakura-fu and the Kanto Kanrei, between the Ogigayatsu Uesugi clan and the Yamanouchi Uesugi clan, and between the two Uesugi clans and the Kasai (家宰) (Dokan OTA and Kageharu NAGAO.

Subsequently, in the Kanto region clashes continued between the Muromachi bakufu and the Kamakura-fu, between the Kamakura-fu and the Kanto Kanrei, between the Ogigayatsu Uesugi clan and the Yamanouchi Uesugi clan, and between the two Uesugi clans and the Kasai (家宰) (Dokan OTA and Kageharu NAGAO).

Subsequently, in the Kanto region clashes continued between the Muromachi bakufu and the Kamakura-fu, between the Kamakura-fu and the Kanto Kanrei, between the Ogigayatsu Uesugi clan and the Yamanouchi Uesugi clan, and between the two Uesugi clans and the Kasai (家宰) (Dokan OTA and Kageharu NAGAO).

sen.j: 上杉禅秀の乱、永享の乱、享徳の乱、長尾景春の乱、長享の乱などの戦乱が起きた。
sen.e: A series of battles were fought: the UESUGI Zenshu no Ran, Eikyo no Ran, Kyotoku no Ran, NAGAO Kageharu no Ran, and Chokyo no Ran and so forth.
A series of battles ensued, including the UESUGI Zenshu no Ran, Eikyo no Ran, Kyotoku no Ran, NAGAO Kageharu no Ran, Chokyo no Ran and others.
A series of battles ensued, including the UESUGI Zenshu no Ran, Eikyo no Ran, Kyotoku no Ran, NAGAO Kageharu no Ran, Chokyo no Ran and others.

sen.j: 伝統的な豪族層が支配する北関東から武蔵国の国府を通って、鎌倉に抜ける鎌倉街道はしばしば戦場になった。
sen.e: The Kamakura Kaido Road stretching from the northern Kanto where traditional powerful families rule to Kamakura via the provincial capital of Musashi Province was often a battleground.
The Kamakura Kaido Road stretching from the northern Kanto where traditional powerful families rule to Kamakura via the provincial capital of Musashi Province was often a battleground.
A frequent battleground was the Kamakura Kaido Road stretching from the northern Kanto, where traditional powerful families ruled, to Kamakura via the provincial capital of Musashi Province.

sen.j: 反面、武蔵国は六浦や品川湊などの良港を抱え、西国や内陸部に広がる「内海」との交易を活発に行っていた。
sen.e: Having good ports such as Mutsuura and Shinagawa Minato Port, on the other hand, Musashi Province was actively engaged in trade with provinces in the west and the 'inland sea' stretching over the internal region.

Having good ports such as Mutsuura and Shinagawa Minato Port, on the other hand, Musashi Province was actively engaged in trade with provinces in the west and the 'inland sea' stretching over the internal region.

Having good ports such as Mutsuura and Shinagawa Minato Port, on the other hand, Musashi Province was actively engaged in trade with provinces in the west and the 'inland sea' stretching over the internal region.

sen.j: 戦国時代_(日本)後期から後北条氏が大きな勢力を振るうようになった。
sen.e: In the late Sengoku period, the Go-Hojo clan became more powerful.
The Go-Hojo clan became more powerful during the late Sengoku period.
The Go-Hojo clan became more powerful during the late Sengoku (Warring States) period.
sen.cmt: 戦国時代に Warring States を補足しました。

sen.j: 1546年（天文15）、河越城の戦いに勝利し覇権を確立した。
sen.e: In 1546, the Go-Hojo clan won the Battle of Kawagoejo, and its power became dominant.
In 1546, the Go-Hojo clan was victorious in the Battle of Kawagoejo and thus became the dominant power.
In 1546, the Go-Hojo clan was victorious in the Battle of Kawagoejo and thus became the dominant power.

sen.j: 江戸城や川越城、岩槻城、鉢形城、滝山城（のちに八王子城）、小机城などに拠点が置かれた。
sen.e: They located headquarters in the Edo-jo Castle, the Kawagoe-jo Castle, the Iwatsuki-jo Castle, the Hachigata-jo Castle, Takiyama-jo Castle (Hachioji-jo Castle), and Kozukue-jo Castle.
They located headquarters in Edo-jo Castle, Kawagoe-jo Castle, Iwatsuki-jo Castle, Hachigata-jo Castle, Takiyama-jo Castle (Hachioji-jo Castle) and Kozukue-jo Castle.
They established operations in the Edo-jo, Kawagoe-jo, Iwatsuki-jo, Hachigata-jo, Takiyama-jo (later Hachioji-jo) and Kozukue-jo castles.

sen.j: 1590年（天正18年）、豊臣秀吉による小田原の役で後北条氏が滅亡。
sen.e: In 1590, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI defeated the Go-Hojo in the Odawara no Eki.
In 1590, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI defeated the Go-Hojo in the Odawara no Eki.
In 1590, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI defeated the Go-Hojo clan in the Odawara no Eki (the Siege of Odawara).
sen.cmt: the Siege of Odawara, clan追加

sen.j: 以後徳川家康が江戸に移った。
sen.e: Ieyasu TOKUGAWA moved to Edo
Ieyasu TOKUGAWA moved to Edo.
Thereafter, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA moved to Edo.

sen.j: 江戸幕府開府以後は徳川政権のお膝元となり、日本政治の中心地となった。
sen.e: After the beginning of the Edo period, Musashi Province became an adjacent area of the Edo Bakufu and the center of politics in Japan.
With the start of the Edo period, Musashi Province became an adjacent area of the Edo bakufu and the center of politics in Japan.
With the start of the Edo period, Musashi Province became an adjacent area of the Edo bakufu and the center of politics in Japan.

sen.j: 1594年(文禄3年)に利根川東遷事業が始まった。
sen.e: In 1594, improvement of the Tone River began.
In 1594, improvement work on the Tone River was started.
In 1594, improvement work on the Tone River was started.

sen.j: 近世初期（1683年（貞享3年）また一説によれば寛永（1622年-1643年）に、下総国葛飾郡からその一部、すなわち隅田川から利根川（現在の江戸川下流）までの地域をあわせ、武蔵国の葛飾郡とした。
sen.e: In the beginning of the early modern period (1683) or some people say, between 1622 to 1643, a part of Katsushika District Shimo-Usa Province from the Sumida River to the Tone River (the downstream of the present-day Edogawa River) was combined to form Katsushika District of Musashi Province.

In the beginning of the early modern period (1683) or, as some people say, between 1622 to 1643, a portion of the Katsushika district in Shimo-Usa Province, from the Sumida River to the Tone River (the downstream of the present-day Edogawa River), was combined to form the Katsushika district of Musashi Province.

In the beginning of the early modern period (1683) or, as some people say, between 1622 to 1643, a portion of the Katsushika district in Shimo-Usa Province, from the Sumida River to the Tone River (the downstream of the present-day Edo-gawa River), was combined to form the Katsushika district of Musashi Province.

sen.j: 東京低地の開発が始まった。
sen.e: Development of the Tokyo lowland began.
Development of the Tokyo lowland was initiated.
Development of the Tokyo lowland was initiated.

sen.j: 1653年（承応2年）には玉川上水が完成し、武蔵野台地の開拓が進んだ。
sen.e: In 1653, the Tamagawa Water Supply System was completed, and the development of the Musashino Plateau moved as planned.
In 1653 the Tamagawa Water Supply System was completed, and the development of the Musashino Plateau moved ahead as planned.
In 1653 the Tamagawa Water Supply System was completed, and the development of the Musashino Plateau moved ahead as planned.

sen.j: 1853年（嘉永6年）、黒船来航によって江戸をはじめ、武蔵国沿岸は脅威に晒された。
sen.e: In 1853, the coastal area of Musashi Province as well as Edo was threatened by the arrival of the black ships of Commodore Perry.
In 1853 the coastal area of Musashi Province, as well as Edo, was threatened by the arrival of the "black ships" of Commodore Perry.
In 1853 the coastal area of Musashi Province, as well as Edo, was threatened by the arrival of the "black ships" of Commodore Perry.

sen.j: 韮山代官所は危機感を強め、品川沖にお台場を建設し、多摩郡などで佐藤彦五郎を編成した。
sen.e: As Nirayama magistrate's office was strongly concerned about the threat, they built Odaiba off the coast of Shinagawa, and organized Hikogoro SATO in areas including the Tama District.
sen.cmt: 定訳不明http://kotobank.jp/word/%E9%9F%AE%E5%B1%B1英辞郎 on the WEB「佐藤彦五郎を編成」はあきらかにおかしいです。
sen.e: Because the office of the Nirayama magistrate was strongly concerned about the threat, they built Odaiba off the coast of Shinagawa and organized Hikogoro SATO in areas such as the Tama district.
Because the office of the Nirayama magistrate was strongly concerned about the threat, they built Odaiba off the coast of Shinagawa and organized Hikogoro SATO in areas such as the Tama district.

sen.j: 八王子千人同心が動員され、近藤勇などが新撰組の中核を担った。
sen.e: Hachioji Sennin Doshin was recruited, and Isami KONDO became one of the leading members in the Shinsen-gum.
Hachioji Sennin Doshin was recruited, and Isami KONDO became one of the leading members in the Shinsen-gum.

Hachioji Sennin Doshin (the police force of Tokugawa shogunate that was based in Hachioji) was mobilized, and Isami KONDO became a leading member of the Shinsen-gumi (a special police force of late Tokugawa shogunate that was based in Kyoto)
sen.cmt: 八王子千人同心、新撰組の説明を補足しました。

sen.j: 1854年（嘉永7年）、武蔵国神奈川の横浜村で日米和親条約（神奈川条約）が締結された。
sen.e: In 1854, the Treaty between the United States of America and the Empire of Japan (Treaty of Kanagawa) was concluded in Yokohama Village, Kanagawa Musashi-no-kuni.
In 1854, the Treaty between the United States of America and the Empire of Japan (Treaty of Kanagawa) was concluded in Yokohama Village, Kanagawa Musashi-no-kuni.
In 1854, the Treaty between the United States of America and the Empire of Japan (the Treaty of Kanagawa) was concluded in Yokohama Village, Kanagawa, Musashi-no-kuni (Musashi Province).
sen.cmt: カンマ追加 Musashi-no-kuniに (Musashi Province)追加

sen.j: 明治維新とそれに続く東京奠都によって首都機能が山城国の平安京（京都）から、武蔵国の東京（旧江戸）に遷された。
sen.e: As a result of the Meiji Restoration and the following transfer of the capital to Tokyo, capital function was transferred from Heian-kyo (Kyoto) to Tokyo Musashi-no-kuni (former Edo).
As a result of the Meiji Restoration and subsequent transfer of the capital to Tokyo, the function of the capital was transferred from Heian-kyo (Kyoto) to Tokyo Musashi-no-kuni (formerly Edo).
As a result of the Meiji Restoration and the capital's subsequent transfer to Tokyo, the function of the capital was transferred from Heian-kyo (Kyoto) to Tokyo in Musashi Province (formerly Edo).

tit.j: 国府・国分寺・国分尼寺・安国寺・利生塔・一宮以下・総社
tit.e: Provincial capital, provincial monastery, provincial nunnery, Ankoku-ji Temple ("Temple for National Pacification") (安国寺), Rishoto Pagoda, below Ichinomiya, shrine enshrining several gods
tit.cmt: 英辞郎 on the WEB定訳不明http://ci.nii.ac.jp/naid/110004657399/Webster's Online Dictionary
tit.e: Provincial capital, provincial monastery, provincial nunnery, Ankoku-ji Temple ("Temple for National Pacification") (安国寺), Rishoto Pagoda, below Ichinomiya, a shrine that enshrines several gods

Provincial capital, provincial monastery, provincial nunnery, Ankoku-ji Temple (Temple for National Pacification) (安国寺), Rishoto Pagoda, Ichinomiya (first shrine) and subsequent shrines; a shrine that enshrines several gods
tit.cmt: " "削除 一宮以下 を、Ichinomiya (first shrine) and subsequent shrines としました

sen.j: 国府は多磨郡にあった。
sen.e: Provincial capital was located in Tama District.
The provincial capital was located in the Tama district.
The provincial capital was located in the Tama district.

sen.j: 現在の東京都府中市 (東京都)にあり、関連施設が発掘されている。
sen.e: The area matches the present-day Fuchu City Tokyo (Tokyo Prefecture), and associated facilities have been unearthed.
The area corresponds to the present-day Fuchu City, Tokyo (Tokyo Prefecture), and associated facilities have been unearthed.
The area corresponds to the present-day Fuchu City, Tokyo (Tokyo Prefecture), and associated facilities have been unearthed.

sen.j: 国庁は現在の大國魂神社の敷地の東半分を西端とし、府中駅南側の市街地部分に存在したと考えられている（武蔵国府関連遺跡）。
sen.e: Kokucho (国庁) is believed to have been located in the urban area to the south of Fuchu Station (its western side ending at the eastern half of the ground of the Okunitama Shrine): Musashi-kokufu-kanren-iseki (武蔵国府関連遺跡).

Kokucho (国庁) is believed to have been located in the urban area to the south of Fuchu Station (its western side ending at the eastern half of the ground of the Okunitama Shrine): Musashi-kokufu-kanren-iseki (武蔵国府関連遺跡).

The provincial capital is believed to have been located in the urban area to the south of what is now Fuchu Station (its western side ending at the eastern half of the grounds of the present-day Okunitama-jinja Shrine) (Musashi-kokufu-kanren-iseki (武蔵国府関連遺跡) (associated remains of the provincial capital of Musashi)).
sen.cmt: (武蔵国府関連遺跡) を(associated remains of the provincial capital of Musashi)と補足しました。 「国庁」は「国府」ではないかと解釈し、provincial capital と訳しました。

sen.j: 国府津は、品川湊であったという説がある。
sen.e: Some people believe that Kouzu was located in Shinagawa Minato.
Some people believe that Kouzu was located in Shinagawa Minato.
Some people believe that Kouzu was located in Shinagawa Minato.

sen.j: 国分寺は現在の東京都国分寺市西元町にあった。
sen.e: The provincial monastery was located in present-day Nishimotomachi Kokubunji City Tokyo..
The provincial monastery was located in what is now Nishimotomachi Kokubunji City, Tokyo.
The provincial monastery was located in what is now Nishimotomachi, Kokubunji City, Tokyo.

sen.j: その法燈を継承する寺院として同地に医王山最勝院国分寺（本尊：薬師如来）がある。
sen.e: There is a temple in the area called the Iozan Saisho-in Provincial Monastery (principal image: Yakushi-nyorai) to have inherited the light of Buddhism.
There is a temple in the area called the Iozan Saisho-in Provincial Monastery (principal image, Yakushi-nyorai), which is said to have inherited the light of Buddhism.
There is a temple in the area called the Iozan Saisho-in Provincial Monastery (principal image, Yakushi-nyorai), which is said to have inherited the light of Buddhism.

sen.j: 国分尼寺は未詳。
sen.e: The provincial nunnery is unknown.
The provincial nunnery is unknown.
The provincial nunnery is unknown.

sen.j: 安国寺は東京都府中市片町の龍門山等持院高安寺（本尊：釈迦如来）と埼玉県越谷市大泊の大龍山東光院安国寺（本尊：阿弥陀如来）が法燈を受け継ぐ。
sen.e: The Ryumonsan Tojiin Koan-ji Temple (principal image: Shaka-nyorai) in Katamachi Fuchu City Tokyo, and the Ryumonsan Tojiin Koan-ji Temple (principal image: Shaka-nyorai) in Odomari Koshigaya City Saitama Prefecture, both inherited the light of Buddhism. from the Ankoku-ji Temple.

The Ryumonsan Tojiin Koan-ji Temple (principal image: Shaka-nyorai) in Katamachi Fuchu City, Tokyo, and the Ryumonsan Tojiin Koan-ji Temple (principal image: Shaka-nyorai) in Odomari Koshigaya City, Saitama Prefecture, both inherited the light of Buddhism from the Ankoku-ji Temple.

As for Ankoku-ji Temple, the Ryumonsan Toji-in Koan-ji Temple (principal image, Shaka-nyorai) in Katamachi, Fuchu City, Tokyo, and the Dairyuzan Toko-in Ankoku-ji Temple (principal image, Amida-nyorai) in Odomari, Koshigaya City, Saitama Prefecture, both inherited the light of Buddhism.

sen.j: 利生塔は未詳である。
sen.e: The Rishoto Pagoda is unknown.
The Rishoto Pagoda is unknown.
The Rishoto Pagoda is unknown.

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳には大社2座2社・小社42座の計44座が記載されている。
sen.e: The Engi Shiki Jimmyo-Cho contains information on 2 gods and 2 grand shrines, and 42 gods, totaling 44 gods.
The Engi Shiki Jimmyo-Cho contains information on two gods and two grand shrines, as well as 42 gods, totaling 44 gods.
The Engishiki Jimmyo-Cho (a list of shrines) contains information on two gods and two grand shrines, as well as 42 gods, for a total of 44 gods.
sen.cmt: Engishikiとしました。 神名帳を a list of shrines と補足しました。

sen.j: 大社は足立郡の氷川神社と児玉郡の金佐奈神社（現 金鑽神社）で、どちらも名神大社に列している。
sen.e: The Hikawa Shrine in Adachi District and the Kanasana Shrine (present-day Kanasana Shrine) in Kodama District are big shrines, both belonging to the Myojin Taisha Shrine.
The Hikawa Shrine in the Adachi district and the Kanasana Shrine (present-day Kanasana Shrine) in the Kodama district are large shrines belonging to the Myojin Taisha Shrine.

The Hikawa-jinja Shrine in the Adachi District and the Kanasana (金佐奈)-jinja Shrine (present-day Kanasana (金鑽)-jinja Shrine) in the Kodama District are large shrines belonging to the Myojin Taisha Shrine.
sen.cmt: jinjaを追加 「金佐奈」と 「金鑽」の漢字表記を追加して違いを出しました。

sen.j: 総社は大國魂神社 (府中市)（東京都府中市宮町）で、別名・六所宮と称し、武蔵国内の一宮から六宮までの祭神が祀られている。
sen.e: The Okunitama Shrine in Miyamachi Fuchu City Tokyo is a shrine enshrining several gods, is also referred to as Rokusho-no-miya Shrine (六所宮), and enshrinis gods of the first to sixth 'miya' as follows:
The Okunitama Shrine in Miyamachi Fuchu City, Tokyo, is a shrine to several gods; it is also referred to as Rokusho-no-miya Shrine (六所宮) and enshrines gods of the first to sixth 'miya,' as follows:

The Okunitama-jinja Shrine in Miyamachi, Fuchu City, Tokyo, is a shrine to several gods; it is also referred to as Rokusho-no-miya Shrine (六所宮) and enshrines gods of the first to sixth 'miya,' as follows:

sen.j: 一宮 小野神社 (東京都)（東京都多摩市一ノ宮。
sen.e: Ichinomiya: Ono Shrine (Tokyo Prefecture), (Ichinomiya Tama City Tokyo)
Ichinomiya: Ono Shrine (Tokyo Prefecture), (Ichinomiya Tama City Tokyo)
Ichinomiya: Ono-jinja Shrine (Tokyo Prefecture), (Ichinomiya, Tama City, Tokyo)

sen.j: 主祭神：小野大神＝天下春命）
sen.e: Main enshrined deity (主祭神): Ono-no-okami (Amanoshitaharu-no-mikoto)
Main enshrined deity (主祭神): Ono-no-okami (Amanoshitaharu-no-mikoto)
Main enshrined deity (主祭神): Ono-no-okami (Amanoshitaharu-no-mikoto)

sen.j: 二宮 二宮神社（東京都あきる野市二宮。
sen.e: Ninomiya: Ninomiya Shrine (Ninomiya Akiruno City Tokyo)
Ninomiya: Ninomiya Shrine (Ninomiya Akiruno City Tokyo)
Ninomiya: Ninomiya-jinja Shrine (Ninomiya, Akiruno City, Tokyo)

sen.j: 主祭神：小河大神＝国常立尊）
sen.e: Main enshrined deity Ogawa-no-okami (Kuninotokotachi no Mikoto (eternal god of the land))
Main enshrined deity Ogawa-no-okami (Kuninotokotachi no Mikoto (eternal god of the land))
Main enshrined deity: Ogawa-no-okami (Kuninotokotachi no Mikoto (eternal god of the land))

sen.j: 三宮 氷川神社（埼玉県さいたま市大宮区高鼻町。
sen.e: Sannomiya: Hikawa Shrine (Takahana-cho Omiya Ward Saitama Ｃity Saitama Prefecture)
Sannomiya: Hikawa Shrine (Takahana-cho Omiya Ward Saitama Ｃity Saitama Prefecture)
Sannomiya: Hikawa-jinja Shrine (Takahana-cho, Omiya Ward, Saitama City, Saitama Prefecture)

sen.j: 主祭神：氷川大神＝須佐之男命、稲田姫命）
sen.e: Main enshrined deity: (Hikawa-no-Okami)
Main enshrined deity: (Hikawa-no-Okami)
Main enshrined deity: Hikawa-no-Okami (Susanoo-no-mikoto, Inadahime-no-mikoto)

sen.j: 四宮 秩父神社（埼玉県秩父市番場町。
sen.e: Yonnomiya; Chichibu Shrine (Bambamachi Chichibu City Saitama Prefecture)
Yonnomiya; Chichibu Shrine (Bambamachi Chichibu City Saitama Prefecture)
Yonnomiya: Chichibu-jinja Shrine (Banbamachi, Chichibu City, Saitama Prefecture)

sen.j: 主祭神：秩父大神＝八意思兼命、知知夫彦命）
sen.e: Main enshrined deity: Yagokoroomoikane-no-mikoto, Chichibuhiko-no-mikoto
Main enshrined deity: Yagokoroomoikane-no-mikoto, Chichibuhiko-no-mikoto
Main enshrined deity: Chichibu-no-okami (Yagokoroomoikane-no-mikoto, Chichibuhiko-no-mikoto)

sen.j: 五宮 金鑽神社（埼玉県神川町二宮。
sen.e: Gonomiya: Kanasana Shrine (Ninomiya Kamikawa-machi Saitama Prefecture)
Gonomiya: Kanasana Shrine (Ninomiya Kamikawa-machi Saitama Prefecture)
Gonomiya: Kanasana-jinja Shrine (Ninomiya, Kamikawa-machi, Saitama Prefecture)

sen.j: 主祭神：金佐奈大神＝天照大神、素盞鳴尊）
sen.e: Main enshrined deity: Kanasana-no-okami (Amaterasu-omikami, Susanoo-no-mikoto)
Main enshrined deity: Kanasana-no-okami (Amaterasu-omikami, Susanoo-no-mikoto)
Main enshrined deity: Kanasana-no-okami (Amaterasu-omikami, Susanoo-no-mikoto)

sen.j: 六宮 杉山神社（比定社が複数あるが、多くは横浜市内に集中する）
sen.e: Rokunomiya: Sugiyama Shrine (there are various 比定社, but most of them are in Yokohama City.)
Rokunomiya: This is Sugiyama-jinja Shrine (there are various 比定社, but most of them are in Yokohama City).
Rokunomiya: Sugiyama-jinja Shrine (there are various Hiteisha (比定社) (shrines judged to be equivalent) of this shrine, but most of them are located in Yokohama City.)
sen.cmt: 比定社を(shrines judged to be equivalent) と補足しました。参考にしたウェブサイトは [http://blog.goo.ne.jp/massy55/m/200512] 2005年12月17日の記事内の説明です。

sen.j: 上記のように、一宮は元々は小野神社であったが、戦国時代 (日本)にそれまでの三宮の氷川神社が並存するようになった。
sen.e: As shown above, the Ichinomiya was originally the Ono Shrine, but during the Sengoku period (Japan), the Hikawa Shrine, former Sannomiya, served as the Ichinomiya.
As shown above, the Ichinomiya was originally the Ono Shrine, but during the Sengoku period (Japan) the Hikawa Shrine (the former Sannomiya) served as the Ichinomiya.
As shown above, the Ichinomiya was originally the Ono-jinja Shrine, but during the Sengoku period (Japan) the Hikawa-jinja Shrine (the former Sannomiya) served as the Ichinomiya.

sen.j: 氷川神社が一宮と称されるようになってからは、五宮の金鑽神社が二宮とされるようになった。
sen.e: After the Hikawa Shrine was referred to as the Ichinomiya, the Kanasana Shrine, the Gonomiya, was referred to as the Ninomiya.
After Hikawa Shrine was referred to as Ichinomiya, the Kanasana Shrine (the Gonomiya), was referred to as Ninomiya.
After Hikawa-jinja Shrine was referred to as Ichinomiya, the Kanasana-jinja Shrine (the Gonomiya), was referred to as Ninomiya.

sen.j: また、さいたま市緑区 (さいたま市)宮本の氷川女体神社も元は氷川神社から分かれたものであり、江戸時代以降一宮とされるようになった。
sen.e: Additionally, the Hikawa Nyotai Shrine in Miyamoto Midori Ward Saitama City was originally separated form the Hikawa Shrine, and after the Edo period, has been treated as the Ichinomiya.
Additionally, the Hikawa Nyotai Shrine in Miyamoto Midori ward of Saitama City was originally separated from the Hikawa Shrine, and subsequent to the Edo period it has been treated as the Ichinomiya.

Additionally, the Hikawa-nyotai-jinja Shrine at Miyamoto, in the Midori ward of Saitama City, was originally separated from Hikawa-jinja Shrine, and subsequent to the Edo period it has been treated as Ichinomiya.
